transcript:
Patient: I think that covers everything I wanted to focus on today. I'm looking forward to discussing strategies for maintaining my progress after our sessions end.

Therapist: That's a great topic to explore, Alex. Before we dive into that, let's review your homework from the last session. How did you find using the thought records and Positive Data Log throughout the week?

Patient: I found the thought records helpful, especially when I was feeling overwhelmed at work. It allowed me to step back and challenge some of those negative thoughts. The Positive Data Log was a bit more challenging for me. I struggled to identify positive experiences or emotions, especially on days when I was feeling really low.

Therapist: It's great to hear that you found the thought records useful in managing overwhelming thoughts at work. It's also understandable that the Positive Data Log was more challenging. When we're feeling low, it can be difficult to recognize the positives. Let's explore this further. Can you think of a specific moment when you struggled to identify a positive experience or emotion for your log?

Patient: Yeah, there was one day last week when I received some critical feedback from my boss. I immediately felt like a failure and couldn't shake off that feeling for the rest of the day. When I tried to think of something positive to write in my log, I drew a blank.

Therapist: That sounds like a tough situation, Alex. Critical feedback can be difficult to receive, especially when we're already feeling vulnerable. Let's break this down using the CBT triangle. What thoughts were going through your mind when you received the feedback?

Patient: I thought, "I'm not good enough," "I'll never be able to meet my boss's expectations," and "I'm going to lose my job."

Therapist: And how did those thoughts make you feel?

Patient: I felt anxious, sad, and hopeless. I couldn't concentrate on my work for the rest of the day.

Therapist: I can understand why you felt that way, given the thoughts you were having. Now, let's look at the behavior component of the CBT triangle. What did you do after receiving the feedback?

Patient: I withdrew from my colleagues and avoided speaking to my boss for the rest of the day. I also skipped my lunch break and stayed late at work, trying to make up for my perceived shortcomings.

Therapist: It's interesting to see how your thoughts, feelings, and behaviors are all interconnected. The critical feedback triggered negative thoughts, which led to feelings of anxiety and sadness, and then influenced your behaviors, such as withdrawing and overworking. Let's try to challenge some of those negative thoughts using the thought record. What evidence do you have that contradicts the thought "I'm not good enough"?

Patient: Well, I've been in this job for over 20 years, and I've received positive feedback and promotions during that time. I've also successfully completed many projects and have good relationships with most of my colleagues.

Therapist: That's great evidence to challenge the thought "I'm not good enough." What about the thought "I'll never be able to meet my boss's expectations"?

Patient: I guess that's an overgeneralization. There have been times when I've met and even exceeded my boss's expectations. It's not fair to assume that I'll never be able to do that again.

Therapist: Excellent point, Alex. You've identified the cognitive distortion of overgeneralization. What about the thought "I'm going to lose my job"?

Patient: That's probably a bit of catastrophizing. One piece of critical feedback doesn't necessarily mean I'm going to lose my job. I've had challenges at work before and have always managed to overcome them.

Therapist: Great work, Alex! You've successfully challenged those negative thoughts using evidence and identified the cognitive distortions at play. Now, let's see if we can find a positive experience or emotion to add to your Positive Data Log from that day. Did anything good happen, no matter how small?
